entity1.name: Bicycle
entity1.description: A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by human power.

entity2.name: bicycle
entity2.description: A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by the rider, typically with pedals and a simple frame.

entity3.name: 19th century
entity3.description: The period of time from 1801 to 1900, characterized by significant industrial and technological advancements.

entity4.name: carbon fiber
entity4.description: A strong, lightweight material made from thin fibers of carbon, used in various applications requiring high strength-to-weight ratio.

entity5.name: Baron Karl von Drais
entity5.description: A German inventor who created an early version of the bicycle called the 'draisine' in the early 19th century.

entity6.name: Draisine
entity6.description: An early two-wheeled vehicle without pedals, invented by Baron Karl von Drais in the early 19th century. It was propelled by the rider pushing off the ground with their feet.

entity7.name: draisine
entity7.description: An early human-powered vehicle, often considered a precursor to the bicycle.

entity8.name: mid-19th century
entity8.description: A period in history that spans from the 1850s to the 1860s.

entity9.name: bicycle
entity9.description: A human-powered vehicle with two wheels, typically propelled by pedals.

entity10.name: velocipede
entity10.description: An early type of bicycle that featured pedals attached directly to the front wheel, also known as the 'boneshaker'.

entity11.name: boneshaker
entity11.description: An early type of bicycle that was a significant improvement over the draisine, offering a smoother ride and greater speed.

entity12.name: draisine
entity12.description: An early form of bicycle invented by Baron Karl von Drais, which was improved upon by the boneshaker.

entity13.name: bicycle
entity13.description: A vehicle with two wheels propelled by foot pedals, used for transportation or recreation.

entity14.name: high-wheel bicycle
entity14.description: An early type of bicycle characterized by a large front wheel and a much smaller rear wheel, popular in the late 19th century.

entity15.name: penny-farthing
entity15.description: Another name for the high-wheel bicycle, named after British coins to describe its size difference between the two wheels.

entity16.name: bicycle
entity16.description: A vehicle with two wheels, typically propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars.

entity17.name: front wheel
entity17.description: The larger wheel located at the front of the bicycle, contributing to its distinctive appearance and high center of gravity.

entity18.name: rear wheel
entity18.description: The smaller wheel located at the back of the bicycle, providing support and balance in conjunction with the front wheel.

entity19.name: penny-farthing
entity19.description: A type of bicycle popular in the 19th century, characterized by a large front wheel and a much smaller rear wheel.

entity20.name: wealthy gentlemen
entity20.description: A class of affluent men who had the means to afford expensive hobbies or pastimes, such as riding a penny-farthing.

entity21.name: safety bicycle
entity21.description: A type of bicycle that was safer and more comfortable to ride, leading to increased popularity in the late 19th century.

entity22.name: late 19th century
entity22.description: The period from around 1870 to 1900, characterized by significant technological and social changes.

entity23.name: safety bicycle
entity23.description: A type of bicycle that features two wheels of equal size, a chain drive system, and pneumatic tires, designed to be more stable, comfortable, and efficient than earlier bicycles.

entity24.name: safety bicycle
entity24.description: A type of bicycle that was safer and easier to ride than its predecessors, leading to increased popularity in the late 19th century.

entity25.name: cycling
entity25.description: The activity or sport of riding bicycles, which gained significant popularity with the introduction of the safety bicycle.

entity26.name: bicycle
entity26.description: A vehicle with two wheels propelled by foot pedals, used for transportation or recreation.

entity27.name: 20th century
entity27.description: The period from 1901 to 2000, characterized by significant technological and social changes.

entity28.name: steel
entity28.description: A strong and durable metal alloy, primarily composed of iron with a small percentage of carbon.

entity29.name: bicycle frames
entity29.description: The structural framework of a bicycle that supports the rider and other components such as wheels, pedals, and seats.

entity30.name: aluminum
entity30.description: A lightweight, durable metal used as an alternative to steel in various applications.

entity31.name: titanium
entity31.description: A strong, corrosion-resistant metal that is lighter than steel and often used in high-performance applications.

entity32.name: steel
entity32.description: A common alloy of iron and carbon, widely used for its strength and durability in construction and manufacturing.

entity33.name: 20th century
entity33.description: A period of 100 years from the year 1901 to 2000.

entity34.name: carbon fiber
entity34.description: A strong and lightweight material made from thin fibers of carbon, used in various applications including bicycle construction.

entity35.name: Carbon fiber frames
entity35.description: A type of frame material used in bicycles, known for being lightweight, strong, and aerodynamic.

entity36.name: Competitive racing
entity36.description: A form of sport where participants compete against each other to determine the fastest rider or team.

entity37.name: High-performance cycling
entity37.description: Cycling that focuses on achieving high speeds and optimal performance, often associated with professional or elite cyclists.

entity38.name: carbon fiber
entity38.description: A strong, lightweight material used in various applications including bicycle manufacturing.

entity39.name: bicycle manufacturing
entity39.description: The process of designing and producing bicycles for commercial sale.

entity40.name: racing bikes
entity40.description: High-performance bicycles designed for competitive cycling events.

entity41.name: bicycles
entity41.description: A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by pedals and steered with handlebars attached to the front wheel.

entity42.name: racing bikes
entity42.description: A type of bicycle designed for speed, typically with dropped handlebars and a more aerodynamic riding position.

entity43.name: cruisers
entity43.description: A type of bicycle designed for comfort, often featuring upright seating positions and wide tires suitable for casual riding.

entity44.name: electric bikes
entity44.description: A type of bicycle equipped with an electric motor to assist the rider, allowing for easier and longer rides.

entity45.name: bicycle
entity45.description: A two-wheeled vehicle propelled by pedals, used for transportation and recreation.

entity47.name: cars

entity48.name: public transportation
entity48.description: A shared transport service that is available for use by the general public, typically provided by government or private operators.

entity49.name: Tour de France
entity49.description: A famous multi-stage bicycle race primarily held in France, known for its challenging routes and prestigious status in the world of cycling.
